citeinfo.origin: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research (OAR), Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory (PMEL)
citeinfo.title: CO2 Distributions in the Equatorial Pacific during the 1991-1992 ENSO Event

descript.abstract: As part of the U.S. JGOFS Equatorial Pacific Process Study, measurements of CO species concentrations were made in the atmosphere and in the surface waters of the central and eastern equatorial Pacific during the boreal spring and autumn of 1992. Surface water fCO data indicate significant differences between the springtime El Ni￱o conditions and the autumn post-El Ni￱o conditions. The autumn fugacity (fCO) maxima were approximately 15-55 µatm higher than in the spring. The lower surface fCO values in the spring data set were the result of: (i) advection of CO-depleted water from the west at the equator near 170°W; and (ii) reduced upwelling and lower fCO distributions as consequence of lighter zonal winds in the eastern Pacific from 140°W to 110°W. Assuming the springtime data are representative of the El Ni￱o conditions and the autumn data are representative of the post-El Ni￱o conditions, it is estimated that the net annual CO flux during the 1991-92 ENSO period to be 0.3 Gt C. Over 60% of this flux occurred during the 4-month period in the autumn when fCO2 values were close to normal. The net annual reduction of the ocean-atmosphere CO flux during the 1991-92 El Ni￱o is estimated to be on the order of 0.5-0.7 Gt C.
